overview.brief_description: Two thousand years of history unfold along the Seine—from Gothic cathedrals to Haussmann boulevards, hidden courtyards to world-class museums. Paris is where painters found light, writers found voice, and every traveler finds something unforgettable. Mornings begin with flaky croissants and café crème at zinc-topped bars; afternoons drift between masterpiece-filled galleries and sun-dappled Luxembourg chairs; evenings crescendo with Seine-side strolls as the Eiffel Tower sparkles on the hour. This is a city that rewards both the iconic bucket list and the aimless wander—where ducking down a cobblestone lane might reveal a century-old fromagerie, a jazz cellar, or a pocket garden tucked behind wrought-iron gates.

sections.title: A Living Museum
sections.content: Paris offers an unparalleled concentration of iconic landmarks within its compact city center. From the soaring silhouette of the Eiffel Tower to the medieval majesty of Notre-Dame Cathedral, the city's signature monuments provide a backdrop to daily life. Beyond these famous sites, Paris reveals itself through charming neighborhoods, hidden gardens, and architectural wonders spanning centuries of history.

sections.title: Cultural Capital
sections.content: Home to world-class museums like the Louvre, Musée d'Orsay, and Centre Pompidou, Paris holds an unrivaled artistic heritage. The city continues its tradition as a center for creativity, with vibrant theater scenes, music venues, and independent galleries throughout its diverse districts. Paris embraces both classical traditions and cutting-edge innovation across all art forms.

sections.title: Gastronomic Paradise
sections.content: Parisian cuisine encompasses everything from neighborhood bistros to Michelin-starred establishments, traditional boulangeries to experimental fusion restaurants. The city celebrates food as an essential pleasure, whether enjoying café culture, exploring specialty food shops, or sampling the offerings at vibrant markets like Rue Mouffetard or Marché d'Aligre.

sections.title: Elegant Lifestyle
sections.content: The Parisian way of life emphasizes aesthetic appreciation and sensory pleasures. Residents and visitors alike embrace café terraces for people-watching, stroll through landscaped gardens, and appreciate the city's architectural harmony. Paris balances cosmopolitan sophistication with everyday moments of beauty and leisure.

why_visit.intro: Paris rewards visitors with experiences that range from grand spectacles to intimate discoveries, offering something for every type of traveler.

highlights.title: Iconic Sights
highlights.content: The city's world-famous landmarks provide unforgettable experiences, from ascending the Eiffel Tower to admiring the views from Sacré-Cœur in Montmartre. Each monument offers a unique perspective on Parisian history and culture.

highlights.title: Artistic Treasures
highlights.content: Paris houses some of humanity's greatest artistic achievements, from the Mona Lisa at the Louvre to Monet's Water Lilies at l'Orangerie. The city itself inspired countless artists, writers, and musicians with its beauty and energy.

highlights.title: Distinct Neighborhoods
highlights.content: Each Parisian district offers its own character—from the medieval streets of Le Marais to the bohemian atmosphere of Montmartre, the literary cafés of Saint-Germain-des-Prés to the multicultural energy of Belleville.

highlights.title: Culinary Excellence
highlights.content: From morning croissants to evening wine tastings, Paris celebrates exceptional food experiences. Visitors can discover traditional French classics, international influences, and innovative contemporary cuisine throughout the city.

highlights.title: Fashion & Shopping
highlights.content: As a global fashion capital, Paris offers shopping experiences ranging from luxury boutiques to charming markets. The city's department stores like Galeries Lafayette are destinations in themselves, while neighborhoods like Le Marais feature independent designers.

highlights.title: Riverside Beauty
highlights.content: The Seine River provides a picturesque backdrop for exploration, whether strolling along its banks, relaxing in a riverside park, or taking an evening boat cruise to see the illuminated monuments.

transport.public_transport: Paris has an extensive public transportation network including metro, buses, and RER trains. The Metro is the fastest way to navigate the city with 16 lines serving 302 stations.
transport.passes: Consider the Paris Visite pass for unlimited travel or Navigo Easy for pay-as-you-go options.

spring.description: Paris blooms with flowering gardens and longer days perfect for outdoor exploration. Sidewalk cafés become lively social hubs, and the moderate temperatures make walking the city a pleasure.

summer.description: The city embraces outdoor living with special events like Paris Plages (urban beaches) and open-air cinema in Parc de la Villette. Longer daylight hours mean extended evening activities.
considerations: Some local businesses close in August

fall.description: Autumn brings comfortable temperatures and cultural renewal as museums launch new exhibitions. Parks display beautiful fall colors, and harvest-inspired menus appear in restaurants.

winter.description: Paris offers a cozy atmosphere with festive holiday decorations, seasonal markets, and indoor cultural activities. Lower tourist numbers mean more authentic experiences at major attractions.
considerations: Some outdoor attractions have limited hours

best_time_to_visit.summary: Paris shines in spring (April–June) and early fall (September–October), when café terraces buzz, gardens bloom or turn golden, and temperatures are comfortable for walking. July brings long evenings and big events but also peak crowds and higher prices; in August some boutiques and small restaurants close for holidays. Winter (November–February) is quieter and cozy—think museum days, patisserie stops, and sparkling holiday lights—while March gradually warms with occasional showers.

Must Do.optimal_time: Weekday mornings; winter for fewer crowds

Must Do.activity: Stroll the Seine and Île de la Cité

Best in Summer.activity: Picnic in Luxembourg or Tuileries Gardens

Best in Winter.activity: Christmas lights on Champs‑Élysées & department store windows
Skate rink at Hôtel de Ville or Tuileries

Rainy Day Favorites.activity: Covered passages shopping (Galerie Vivienne, Passages Jouffroy)

Local Experiences.activity: Boulangerie run and canal picnic (Canal Saint‑Martin)

overview.subtitle: Where Art, Romance & Joie de Vivre Come Alive

sites.name: Eiffel Tower
sites.description: Arguably the most iconic silhouette in Paris, the **Eiffel Tower** (completed 1889) soars over the Champ de Mars, its lattice ironwork framing the sky. By day it draws the eye upward against the clouds; by night the tower **glitters with 20,000 lights** for five minutes each hour. Visiting at dusk lets you see the city bathed in golden light and then twinkling as the lights come alive.
sites.price_range: Moderate to High (depending on level accessed)
sites.seasonal_notes: Open late in summer (often until midnight) for better evening views.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve tickets well in advance on the official site to avoid long queues and ensure your preferred time slot.

opening_hours.notes: Closing extended in summer; last elevator up ~30 minutes before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening metro trains stop ~midnight; plan return accordingly.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Montparnasse Tower nearby for indoor view

sites.name: Arc de Triomphe
sites.description: Standing at the western end of the Champs-Élysées, the **Arc de Triomphe** commands a grand vista of twelve radiating avenues. Climb its **284-step spiral staircase** or take the partial elevator to reach the rooftop panorama — from here, the Eiffel Tower, La Défense, and the city’s boulevards unfold in a sweeping ring of Parisian splendor. The interior also houses a small museum about the arch’s construction and symbolism.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open later in peak season (April–Sept) until ~23:00; in off-peak until ~22:30.
sites.booking_tips: Buy tickets ahead via the official monument site to skip lines and reserve times.

opening_hours.notes: Last admission 45 minutes before closing. Closed on some holiday mornings.

transit.last_train_consideration: Metro lines 1, 2, 6 and RER A converge here; evening coverage is good but check schedules.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Dôme des Invalides nearby

sites.name: Louvre Museum
sites.description: The **Louvre Museum**, once a royal palace, now houses one of the world’s most vast and spectacular art collections — **35,000 works** across eight curatorial departments. Wander through halls of ancient sculpture, Renaissance masterpieces, and modern creation. The glass **pyramid entrance** glimmers in daylight, and the courtyards create dramatic spatial dialogues between old and new. A visit in late afternoon gives you a moment of quiet between the crowds and the sunset light across the cour Carrée.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open late (to 21:00) on Wednesdays and Fridays.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve a timed-entry ticket in advance via the official site; use lesser-crowded entrances like Carrousel or Porte des Lions.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Tuesdays. Last entry ~1 hour before closing; rooms begin clearing ~30 min prior.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening train changes at Châtelet can be busy; allow buffer time.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée de l’Orangerie or Musée d’Orsay

sites.name: Notre-Dame de Paris
sites.description: A timeless emblem of Gothic grandeur, **Notre-Dame de Paris** (begun c. 1163) soars with flying buttresses, rose windows, and sculpted gargoyles. Though scarred by fire, its nave, stained glass, and crypts stand restored. Enter in the soft morning or late evening light to sense centuries of prayer and stone in quiet dialogue.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cathedral interior is freely accessible; paid access applies to treasury and tower ascent. During high tourist flow, timed free reservations may reduce wait times. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
sites.booking_tips: Make a (free) timeslot reservation via the official website to smooth your entry. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

opening_hours.notes: Interior access is free; certain areas (treasury, towers) require paid access. Last entry ~30 min before close.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening return via Châtelet hub may be busy; give buffer time.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Explore the crypt or treasury if inclement

sites.name: Sainte-Chapelle
sites.description: One of Paris’s most enchanting jewels, **Sainte-Chapelle** was built in 1248 to house holy relics and is celebrated for its luminous **1,113 stained-glass windows** that bathe the interior in jewel-tone color. The soaring upper chapel is a celestial vault of glass, best seen when sunlight streams through and animates the biblical narratives in glass. A serene, reverent experience awaits midday or late morning.
sites.seasonal_notes: Last entry is ~40 minutes before closing. Admission is free on European Heritage Days and first Sundays (Nov–Mar). :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
sites.booking_tips: Reserve a timed-entry ticket via Monuments Nationaux portal ahead of time to guarantee access. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
sites.neighborhood: Île de la Cité / Boulevard du Palais

opening_hours.notes: Last entry ~40 min before closing; chapel closed Jan 1, May 1, Dec 25. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

transit.last_train_consideration: Return via Châtelet is central but can be crowded in evenings.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Visit Conciergerie next door

sites.name: Panthéon
sites.description: An imposing neoclassical edifice crowning the Latin Quarter hill, the **Panthéon** (by Soufflot, 18th c.) was transformed into the secular mausoleum of France’s greatest minds. Inside, a solemn nave echoes with memory, and in the crypt rest Voltaire, Hugo, Marie Curie, and others. On crisp afternoons, ascend to the dome for panoramic views across Paris rooftops.
sites.seasonal_notes: Panorama (cupola) access requires an extra fee in summer. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
sites.booking_tips: Book tickets in advance via the official Panthéon site to secure entry, especially on peak days. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

opening_hours.weekday: 10:00-18:30 (Apr–Sep) / 10:00-18:00 (Oct–Mar), opening 12:00 on first working Monday monthly :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
opening_hours.notes: Last admission 45 min before closing. Closed Jan 1, May 1, Dec 25. Panoramic dome often closed outside April–Oct. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening trains via Luxembourg may have fewer departures; check schedules.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Use crypt and interior galleries if dome is closed

sites.name: Basilique du Sacré-Cœur de Montmartre
sites.description: Perched atop Montmartre’s hill, the **Sacré-Cœur Basilica** gleams white against the Paris skyline — its Romano-Byzantine domes visible for miles. Inside, the vast mosaic of *Christ in Majesty* radiates gold and azure light across the sanctuary. Climb the **300-step dome** for panoramic views, linger for the sunset bells, and watch the city unfold beneath your feet.
sites.seasonal_notes: The basilica is open daily; the dome may close in winter or bad weather. Continuous adoration since 1885 makes it one of Paris’s most spiritual spaces.
sites.booking_tips: No reservation required for entry; purchase dome tickets on-site. Arrive 30 min before sunset for best light atop the dome.

opening_hours.notes: Last entry ~30 min before close; dome closed during rain or strong winds.

closures.reason: Open with special Christmas Mass schedule only

transit.last_train_consideration: Funicular runs until ~00:30; stairs open later but steep.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor basilica and crypt access

sites.name: Musée d’Orsay
sites.description: A radiant temple of light and color, the **Musée d’Orsay** occupies a converted Beaux-Arts train station overlooking the Seine. Inside, visitors encounter the world’s most celebrated collection of **Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces** — Monet’s water lilies, Degas’s dancers, Van Gogh’s swirls, and Gauguin’s Tahitian hues. The museum’s glass roof floods the galleries with daylight, transforming each canvas into a conversation with the Paris sky.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays. Thursday nocturne (open until 21:45) offers quieter viewing and golden evening light on the Seine.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve timed entry online; Thursdays after 18:00 are serene. Combine visit with nearby Orangerie or Rodin for a full artistic circuit.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and May 1; last admission ~17:00 (Thu 20:45).

transit.last_train_consideration: Thursday night openings end 21:45; check RER C evening frequency.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor galleries and café with Seine views

sites.name: Palais Garnier (Opéra Garnier)
sites.description: An opulent ode to the arts, the **Palais Garnier** (1875) dazzles with marble staircases, gilded foyers, and a ceiling painted by **Marc Chagall**. Beneath its grand chandelier lies the setting that inspired *The Phantom of the Opera*. Guided or self-guided tours reveal intricate mosaics, mirrors, and the red-and-gold auditorium — a living masterpiece of Second Empire luxury and acoustical perfection.
sites.seasonal_notes: Hours vary with performances and in summer (July – Aug reduced hours).
sites.booking_tips: Book tickets for guided or self-guided visits online. On show nights, last tour entry is earlier.

opening_hours.notes: Hours adjust on performance days; last entry 45 min before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: After evening performances, RER A and metro run until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor galleries and covered passages near Opéra

sites.name: Conciergerie
sites.description: Once the royal palace of the Capetian kings, the **Conciergerie** later became the **Revolutionary tribunal prison** that held Marie-Antoinette before her execution. Today, its vast Gothic halls, rib-vaulted ceilings, and recreated cells immerse visitors in medieval and Revolutionary history. Paired with Sainte-Chapelle next door, it offers a window into centuries of justice and power on the Île de la Cité.
sites.seasonal_notes: Quietest early morning; combined tickets available with Sainte-Chapelle.
sites.booking_tips: Book a timed ticket online via the official Monuments Nationaux site. Audio guide (Histopad) recommended for immersive storytelling.
sites.neighborhood: Île de la Cité / Boulevard du Palais

opening_hours.notes: Last entry ~17:15; closed May 1 and Dec 25.

transit.last_train_consideration: Central hub area; allow extra time for security queues at Palais de Justice.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Sainte-Chapelle next door (fully indoor)

sites.name: Musée Rodin
sites.description: Set within a serene 18th-century mansion and tranquil rose gardens, the **Musée Rodin** celebrates the genius of Auguste Rodin. Bronze and marble works such as *The Thinker*, *The Kiss*, and *The Gates of Hell* populate sun-dappled lawns and quiet galleries. The play of natural light on his figures, combined with the scent of roses and the hum of bees, makes this one of Paris’s most poetic escapes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Gardens are most vibrant April–September. Tuesdays closed; free entry first Sundays (Oct–Mar).
sites.booking_tips: Reserve tickets online to skip the queue. Combine with Invalides or Orsay nearby.

opening_hours.notes: Last admission 17:45; closed Jan 1, May 1, Dec 25.

transit.last_train_consideration: Close to central hub; trains run until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor sculpture halls

sites.name: Musée de l’Orangerie
sites.description: An intimate sanctuary of light and color, the **Musée de l’Orangerie** houses Monet’s monumental **Water Lilies** murals — eight vast panels enveloping two oval rooms designed for peaceful contemplation. The lower floors feature works by Cézanne, Renoir, Matisse, and Modigliani, forming a concise yet radiant survey of early modern art in the heart of the Tuileries Gardens.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Tuesdays; late-day visits are calmer. Free entry first Sundays (Oct–Mar).
sites.booking_tips: Reserve a timed entry ticket online to avoid queues; combo tickets with Musée d’Orsay available.

opening_hours.notes: Last admission 17:15; rooms begin clearing 17:45.

transit.last_train_consideration: Metro line 1 and RER A provide reliable late service until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor collection entirely covered

sites.name: Musée Picasso–Paris
sites.description: Housed in a restored 17th-century hôtel particulier in the Marais, the **Musée Picasso–Paris** offers the most comprehensive collection of **Pablo Picasso’s** works anywhere: paintings, sculptures, ceramics, and sketchbooks spanning his prolific career. The airy rooms blend classic French architecture with modern curation, revealing the artist’s evolution from Blue Period introspection to Cubist revolution.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays. Peak mid-afternoon hours see tour groups; mornings are quieter.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve skip-the-line entry online. Combination tickets sometimes offered with Musée Rodin.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Monday; last entry 17:15.

transit.last_train_consideration: Le Marais area remains active late; metro until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Fully indoor visit

sites.name: Centre Pompidou
sites.description: A radical emblem of modern architecture, the **Centre Pompidou** (1977, by Piano & Rogers) wears its pipes, ducts, and escalators on the outside, embodying transparency and motion. Inside unfolds Europe’s largest modern art collection — from Kandinsky to Pollock, Duchamp to Bourgeois — alongside ever-changing installations and a panoramic rooftop terrace overlooking the skyline of Paris.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Tuesdays. Rooftop terrace and restaurant open independently of galleries.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve entry online; avoid peak weekends. Evening visits around 17:00 – 19:00 offer thinner crowds.

opening_hours.notes: Last admission 20:00; rooftop terrace closes earlier in winter.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening exit through Les Halles area offers easy night service.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Fully indoor; rooftop terrace weather-dependent

sites.name: Palais Garnier (Opéra Garnier)
sites.description: 19th-century jewel box by Charles Garnier with grand staircase, Chagall ceiling, and lavish foyers; tours and occasional performances.
sites.seasonal_notes: Hours can shift on performance days and in late July–Aug; check day-of schedule.
sites.booking_tips: Book self-guided or guided tour slots; last entries earlier on show nights.

opening_hours.notes: Open until end of performances; hours vary with events.

transit.last_train_consideration: After evening performances, RER A still frequent; mind last museum entries earlier on show nights.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Galeries Lafayette rooftop (covered access nearby).

sites.name: Conciergerie
sites.description: Medieval royal palace turned prison on Île de la Cité, known for Revolutionary history including Marie-Antoinette’s cell.
sites.seasonal_notes: Joint tickets sometimes offered with Sainte-Chapelle; check for security lines at Palais de Justice.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve a time slot; Histopad tablets available until late afternoon.
sites.neighborhood: Île de la Cité / Boulevard du Palais

opening_hours.notes: Last entry ~17:15; closed May 1 and Dec 25.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening Seine area is lively; allow several extra minutes for security screening.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Sainte-Chapelle next door.

sites.name: Panthéon
sites.description: A neoclassical landmark in the Latin Quarter originally built as a church, now serving as a mausoleum for distinguished French citizens including Voltaire, Rousseau, Marie Curie, and Victor Hugo.
sites.seasonal_notes: Sunny mornings provide ideal lighting inside the dome; expect larger groups in spring and summer.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase skip-the-line tickets or combined passes online. Dome access requires an extra ticket and is closed in winter months.

opening_hours.notes: Last entry ~45 min before close; dome access limited in winter or heavy rain.

transit.last_train_consideration: RER B continues until ~00:30; allow 15 min walk from closing time.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée de Cluny or covered cafés of Rue Soufflot.

sites.name: Les Invalides & Musée de l’Armée
sites.description: Dominated by its gilded dome, **Les Invalides** unites history, architecture, and reverence. Built by Louis XIV to house wounded soldiers, it now shelters the **Musée de l’Armée**, chronicling French military history from medieval armor to World War II, and the solemn **tomb of Napoleon I** beneath a golden cupola that glows at sunset. The mixture of grandeur and quiet reflection makes it one of Paris’s most profound sites.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open daily except first Mondays of each month (Jan–Jun, Oct–Dec). The Dome Church interior shines under afternoon light.
sites.booking_tips: Purchase skip-the-line tickets online; combined passes available with Rodin Museum or Orsay.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Jan 1, May 1, Dec 25; last entry 30 min before close.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening returns well served; short walk to Seine bridges.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor museum galleries

sites.name: Hôtel de Ville de Paris
sites.description: The **Hôtel de Ville** — Paris’s ornate neo-Renaissance city hall — anchors the Right Bank with grandeur and civic pride. Its sculpted façade bears the likenesses of French luminaries, while the square hosts skating rinks in winter and open-air events in summer. Interior tours (by reservation) reveal gilded salons rivaling Versailles in detail.
sites.seasonal_notes: Exterior illuminated at night; occasional temporary closures during official ceremonies.
sites.booking_tips: Free to view exterior anytime; guided interior visits require advance booking via City Hall website.

opening_hours.weekday: 08:00–19:30 (administrative hours) / Facade and square 24 h access
opening_hours.notes: Interior tours by reservation only; check official schedule.

transit.last_train_consideration: Central hub with service until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby BH V Marais arcade or Café Marcel

sites.name: Pont Alexandre III
sites.description: The **Pont Alexandre III** is Paris’s most ornate bridge — an exuberant Belle Époque masterpiece adorned with gilded nymphs, winged horses, and Art Nouveau lamps. Linking the Champs-Élysées with Les Invalides, it frames unforgettable views of the Seine and the Eiffel Tower, especially magical at dusk when its lamps shimmer against the water.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best photographed near golden hour; night lighting from both banks enhances reflections.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket needed; go around blue-hour for photos and minimal crowds.

opening_hours.notes: Lighting typically on from sunset to ~01:00.

transit.last_train_consideration: Bridge easily walkable to Champs-Élysées or Eiffel Tower metro lines.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Grand Palais or Bateaux-Mouches cruise

sites.name: Seine River Cruises (Port de la Bourdonnais / Bateaux Parisiens)
sites.description: Drifting beneath Paris’s bridges on a **Seine River cruise** offers a living postcard of the city — Notre-Dame, the Louvre, and the Eiffel Tower glide by as narration recounts centuries of history. **Bateaux Parisiens**, departing from the foot of the Eiffel Tower, run day and illuminated night cruises, with dining options that pair cuisine and skyline sparkle.
sites.price_range: Moderate to High (depends on cruise type)
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round; covered boats operate in winter; advance bookings recommended in summer.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve online for timed boarding at Port de la Bourdonnais. Arrive 15 min early for boarding and best deck views.
sites.neighborhood: Eiffel Tower / Port de la Bourdonnais

opening_hours.notes: Dinner cruises depart 19:30–21:00; schedules vary with sunset.

transit.last_train_consideration: Late night cruise returns match RER C final departures (~23:00).

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Enclosed boats with panoramic windows

sites.name: Musée Picasso Paris
sites.description: Occupying the 17th-century Hôtel Salé, this museum holds the world’s largest collection of Picasso’s works spanning every creative phase, from Blue Period to late ceramics.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; lighter crowds at opening or late afternoon.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve timed tickets online. Café and rooftop terrace provide breaks between galleries.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Monday; last entry 17:15; museum shop open until 18:30.

transit.last_train_consideration: Metro line 8 runs until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée Carnavalet or Maison Européenne de la Photographie.

sites.name: Jeu de Paume
sites.description: Contemporary photography and video art exhibitions in a neoclassical pavilion within the Tuileries Gardens.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Monday; garden entrance can flood lightly in winter rain—use north entry.
sites.booking_tips: Timed tickets recommended; free on first Sunday of each month.

opening_hours.notes: Last admission 45 min before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening Tue late sessions align with metro until midnight.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Musée de l’Orangerie across the gardens.

sites.name: Centre Pompidou Constellation (2025–2030 Off-site Venues)
sites.description: During the main Centre Pompidou’s renovation, major works tour France and Europe under the ‘Constellation’ banner, with satellite exhibitions hosted at venues such as the Grand Palais Immersif, Bourse de Commerce, and new Pompidou-kiosks across Paris.
sites.seasonal_notes: Rotating schedules 2025–2027; consult Pompidou official listings for current constellation sites.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve online per venue; schedules differ across Paris and regional partner museums.
sites.neighborhood: Grand Palais, Bourse de Commerce, La Villette, and partner galleries

opening_hours.weekend: Varies; late evenings for select immersive shows
opening_hours.notes: Each site maintains its own calendar under Pompidou Constellation program.

seasonal_hours.summer: Extended hours for open-air or immersive programs

closures.reason: Main Pompidou closed for renovation; satellite schedule begins

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening installations often end ~22:00; allow 15–20 min for return travel.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Alternate partner museums or cinemas within Constellation circuit.

sites.name: Musée d’Art Moderne de Paris
sites.description: Dedicated to modern and contemporary art, this museum showcases 20th- and 21st-century masterpieces by artists like Matisse, Delaunay, and Picasso in the striking Palais de Tokyo complex.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; best visited weekday afternoons for calm galleries.
sites.booking_tips: Permanent collections are free; special exhibitions require separate tickets. Combine with nearby Palais de Tokyo.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and certain holidays. Last entry 45 min before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening events sometimes run late; nearby bus routes operate until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Palais de Tokyo exhibitions next door.

sites.name: Petit Palais – Musée des Beaux-Arts de la Ville de Paris
sites.description: Built for the 1900 World’s Fair, this elegant Beaux-Arts palace houses fine arts from antiquity through the early 20th century, with a lush inner courtyard café.
sites.seasonal_notes: Quiet in early mornings; courtyard garden ideal in warm weather.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket required for the permanent collection; special exhibitions are ticketed.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and holidays; last entry 17:15.

seasonal_hours.summer: Standard; courtyard café open extended hours

transit.last_train_consideration: Easy late-evening access via metro 1 until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Musée d’Orsay or Grand Palais Immersif nearby.

sites.name: Musée de Cluny – Musée National du Moyen Âge
sites.description: A medieval jewel showcasing artifacts of daily life and art from the Middle Ages, including the celebrated ‘Lady and the Unicorn’ tapestries.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cool interior even in summer; less busy on weekday mornings.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve timed tickets or use the Paris Museum Pass. Audio guides recommended for tapestry gallery.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Tuesdays; last entry 17:45.

transit.last_train_consideration: Area lively late; RER B to airports runs until ~00:15.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Panthéon or bookstores along Boulevard Saint-Michel.

sites.name: Musée Guimet – Musée National des Arts Asiatiques
sites.description: France’s premier Asian art museum with over 60,000 works from across Asia, including Khmer sculptures, Japanese screens, and Himalayan bronzes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Tuesdays; upper-floor galleries can warm in midsummer afternoons.
sites.booking_tips: Book online; combined tickets available with the Panthéon Bouddhique annex nearby.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Tuesdays; last admission 17:15.

transit.last_train_consideration: Area well-lit at night; easy returns via line 9 until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Palais Galliera or Musée d’Art Moderne.

sites.name: Musée des Arts Décoratifs
sites.description: Part of the Louvre complex, this museum chronicles decorative arts, fashion, and design from the Middle Ages to the present with an emphasis on craftsmanship and creativity.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; late openings on Thursdays until 21:00.
sites.booking_tips: Book online; the temporary fashion exhibits are highly popular and time-slot controlled.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays; last entry 17:15 (or 20:15 Thu).

transit.last_train_consideration: Thursday nocturnes end 21:00; metro 1 operates until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Louvre galleries nearby.

sites.name: Musée Carnavalet – Histoire de Paris
sites.description: Located in two adjoining mansions in the Marais, this museum traces the rich and turbulent history of Paris from its origins to the present day through art, maps, furniture, and historical artifacts.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; pleasant courtyard café in spring and summer.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry to permanent exhibits; book temporary show tickets online.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and some holidays; last entry 17:15.

transit.last_train_consideration: Area quiet by late evening; metro 1 runs until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Musée Picasso or Maison de Victor Hugo nearby.

sites.name: Musée de la Vie Romantique
sites.description: A charming museum in the former home of painter Ary Scheffer, devoted to Romantic-era art and literature with strong links to George Sand and Frédéric Chopin.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; lovely garden café open seasonally from April to October.
sites.booking_tips: Permanent galleries free; temporary exhibitions require tickets available online.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays; café open seasonally 10:00–17:30.

transit.last_train_consideration: Metro lines 2 and 12 run until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée Gustave Moreau (indoor).

sites.name: Palais de Tokyo – Contemporary Art Center
sites.description: Europe’s largest contemporary art center, housed in an immense 1937 building opposite the Eiffel Tower, known for bold, experimental installations and late-night hours.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Tuesdays; café terrace popular on warm nights.
sites.booking_tips: Online booking advised for major installations. Exhibits change every few months.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Tuesdays; last entry ~23:15.

seasonal_hours.summer: Standard; terrace bar open until late

transit.last_train_consideration: Late openings make metro preferable; last train ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor exhibitions unaffected by weather.

sites.name: Musée des Égouts de Paris
sites.description: A fascinating underground museum exploring the city’s extensive sewer system, engineering marvels, and environmental management.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cool year-round; may close temporarily after heavy rain for safety.
sites.booking_tips: Book online due to group limits. Not recommended for visitors sensitive to odors or confined spaces.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and public holidays; last entry 16:15.

transit.last_train_consideration: Allow extra time if visiting during rain; RER C occasionally suspends service.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Musée d’Orsay or Rodin Museum nearby.

sites.name: Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature
sites.description: An eccentric and artful museum in the Marais blending hunting artifacts, taxidermy, and contemporary art, exploring humanity’s relationship with nature.
sites.seasonal_notes: Closed Mondays; special installations rotate often.
sites.booking_tips: Book online—limited capacity and high local interest. Free entry first Sunday monthly.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and some holidays; last entry 17:30.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evenings calm; metro line 1 runs until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Carnavalet Museum.

sites.name: Catacombes de Paris
sites.description: A labyrinthine ossuary beneath southern Paris housing the remains of over six million Parisians, arranged in haunting artistic formations within 18th-century tunnels.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cool (14°C/57°F) year-round; ideal summer activity. Closed Mondays.
sites.booking_tips: Advance online booking mandatory; timed entries strictly enforced. Not suitable for claustrophobia or mobility issues.

opening_hours.notes: Closed Mondays and major holidays; last entry 19:30.

transit.last_train_consideration: Last Catacombs entry 19:30; RER B runs until ~00:20.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: N/A (fully indoor).

sites.name: Parc des Buttes-Chaumont
sites.description: A dramatic 19th-century park in northeastern Paris, known for its steep cliffs, suspension bridge, waterfalls, and the Temple de la Sibylle perched atop an artificial island.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cherry blossoms in spring; picnics and concerts in summer. Some paths close during icy conditions.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket required; arrive early on weekends for quiet walks.

opening_hours.notes: Gates close progressively 30 min before stated time.

closures.reason: Partial path closures for maintenance (lower lake area)

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening exits unlit in winter; metro runs until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Cité des Sciences nearby.

sites.name: Grand Palais Éphémère
sites.description: Facing the Eiffel Tower on the Champ-de-Mars, the **Grand Palais Éphémère** is a striking wood-and-glass structure designed by Jean-Michel Wilmotte. It temporarily replaces the Grand Palais during renovations and hosts art fairs, haute couture shows, and exhibitions beneath its elegant arched roof. Its transparent form frames both the Invalides and the Tower — a symbol of modern Parisian culture in motion.
sites.seasonal_notes: Event-based schedule; check website for current exhibitions and hours.
sites.booking_tips: Book directly via each event organizer or through the official venue site. Entry hours depend on exhibition programming.

opening_hours.notes: Closed between exhibitions; schedules updated online.

transit.last_train_consideration: Central area, well served until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Fully indoor; café nearby

sites.name: Jardin des Tuileries
sites.description: Stretching between the Louvre and Place de la Concorde, the **Jardin des Tuileries** is the historic heart of Parisian promenades. Designed by Le Nôtre in the 17th century, its grand alleys, ornamental ponds, and sculptures invite both flâneurs and families. Carousel music, art installations, and open-air cafés create an elegant rhythm of daily life, especially radiant in late afternoon light.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spring tulips and autumn foliage are stunning; hosts the Tuileries Fun Fair in summer.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry; visit weekdays for quieter strolls.

opening_hours.notes: Closing hours vary slightly with daylight.

transit.last_train_consideration: Central area, multiple late-night metro options.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée de l’Orangerie

sites.name: Cimetière du Père-Lachaise
sites.description: A labyrinth of cobblestone paths shaded by chestnut trees, **Père-Lachaise Cemetery** is both a tranquil park and an open-air museum. Its ornate tombs honor artists, writers, and thinkers — from **Oscar Wilde** and **Chopin** to **Jim Morrison**. The soft hush and filtered light make it one of Paris’s most contemplative walks, rich in symbolism and history.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round; autumn colors are especially atmospheric.
sites.booking_tips: Pick up a free map at the entrance; guided tours available on weekends.

opening_hours.notes: Last entry 15 min before closing; office closed on major holidays.

transit.last_train_consideration: Peripheral location; last metro departures around 00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: None — bring umbrella in case of rain

sites.name: La Villette & Philharmonie de Paris
sites.description: The **Parc de la Villette** blends futuristic architecture with green spaces and performance halls. Its crown jewel, the **Philharmonie de Paris** by Jean Nouvel, shimmers like folded metal, offering world-class acoustics and panoramic terraces. From jazz festivals to science exhibits, La Villette is where culture, design, and community converge in northern Paris.
sites.seasonal_notes: Outdoor events flourish in summer; indoor concerts and expos year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Reserve concert tickets early at Philharmonie’s official site. Family-friendly museum and cinema options nearby.

opening_hours.notes: Exhibits typically open 10:00–18:00; concerts start evenings.

transit.last_train_consideration: Late shows end ~22:30; check last metro schedule.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor Philharmonie or Cité des Sciences

sites.name: Fondation Louis Vuitton
sites.description: Designed by Frank Gehry, this glass-sail architectural marvel in the Bois de Boulogne hosts rotating modern and contemporary art exhibitions.
sites.seasonal_notes: Evening light on the sails is stunning; long queues for blockbuster shows.
sites.booking_tips: Pre-book timed tickets online; shuttle bus runs from Place Charles de Gaulle every 20 min.

opening_hours.notes: Hours vary with exhibitions; last entry ~1 h before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: Late Friday openings align with last metro departures ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor museum; optional stroll in Jardin d’Acclimatation next door.

sites.name: Parc de la Villette
sites.description: A vast urban park integrating architecture, music, and science, featuring themed gardens, the Cité des Sciences, concert halls, and open-air cinema in summer.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best in spring/summer; lawns host festivals and outdoor screenings.
sites.booking_tips: No entry fee; check event calendar for concerts or Cinéma en plein air.

opening_hours.notes: Individual venues (Cité des Sciences, Zénith) follow separate hours.

transit.last_train_consideration: Late events finish before last metro at ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Cité des Sciences or Philharmonie indoor venues.

sites.name: Palais Royal & Gardens
sites.description: A hidden oasis in the 1st arrondissement, the **Palais Royal** combines elegant 17th-century arcades, designer boutiques, and the photogenic **Colonnes de Buren** art installation. Beyond lies a perfectly symmetrical garden framed by lime trees — a quiet sanctuary where Parisians read and sip coffee between the Louvre and Opéra. In spring, chestnut blossoms perfume the air.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best in spring and early autumn. Benches fill quickly at lunchtime.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket required; café terraces open from 08:00.

opening_hours.notes: Palais Royal arcades follow shop hours (~10:00–19:00).

transit.last_train_consideration: Area well served until late; short walk to Louvre metro stops.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Café Kitten or Galerie de Valois arcades

sites.name: Jardin du Luxembourg
sites.description: Commissioned by Marie de Médicis in the 17th century, the **Jardin du Luxembourg** is Paris’s most beloved park — a tapestry of flowerbeds, statues, sailboat ponds, and leafy promenades. Locals play chess, read newspapers, and bask by the Medici Fountain. At golden hour, the palace façade glows against the trees and fountains, epitomizing Parisian leisure at its most elegant.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round; spring and autumn offer the richest colors. Expect music and puppet shows weekends.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry; morning runs or sunset picnics both ideal.

opening_hours.weekday: Opens ~07:30 (winter) / ~07:00 (summer); closes at dusk (21:30 summer / 16:30 winter)
opening_hours.notes: Hours adjust monthly with daylight; last entry 30 min before close.

transit.last_train_consideration: Central area; RER B runs until ~00:30.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Musée du Luxembourg

sites.name: Tour Montparnasse Observation Deck
sites.description: Paris’s tallest skyscraper, offering 360° panoramic views from its 56th-floor observation deck and rooftop terrace, including the best Eiffel Tower vantage point.
sites.seasonal_notes: Indoor deck open year-round; rooftop terrace weather-dependent.
sites.booking_tips: Book online for discounted rates; sunset tickets sell out early.

opening_hours.notes: Extended summer hours; last elevator ~30 min before closing.

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening visits ideal; metro connections plentiful until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Indoor deck remains open in poor weather.

sites.name: Église de la Sainte-Trinité
sites.description: A grand 19th-century Neo-Renaissance church near Opéra, known for its ornate façade, monumental dome, and excellent acoustics for classical concerts.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open daily except during services; cool refuge in summer heat.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket required; check posted schedules for organ recitals.

opening_hours.notes: Masses held mornings and evenings; tourists asked to remain quiet.

closures.reason: Organ maintenance; interior access limited for one week

transit.last_train_consideration: Evening concerts end before metro close (~00:45).

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Nearby Galeries Lafayette rooftop view (indoor access).

sites.name: Canal Saint-Martin
sites.description: A picturesque 19th-century canal stretching through the 10th and 11th arrondissements, lined with cafés, iron footbridges, and popular picnic spots.
sites.seasonal_notes: Bustling in summer; canal-boat cruises operate Apr–Oct.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket for walking; cruise tickets from companies like Canauxrama.

opening_hours.notes: Locks occasionally closed to traffic for maintenance; walking paths remain open.

transit.last_train_consideration: Popular evening stroll; metro lines 5 and 9 run until ~00:45.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Bars and galleries along Quai de Jemmapes.

sites.name: Bois de Boulogne
sites.description: Spanning 2,000 acres on Paris’s western edge, this landscaped park offers lakes, gardens, riding trails, the Fondation Louis Vuitton, and quiet escapes from city bustle.
sites.seasonal_notes: Ideal for cycling and boating April–October; evening areas dimly lit.
sites.booking_tips: Free entry; boat rentals and zoo tickets at additional cost.

opening_hours.notes: Some paths unlit at night; lakes and attractions have separate hours.

transit.last_train_consideration: Best visited by day; limited lighting after dusk.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Fondation Louis Vuitton indoor galleries nearby.

sites.name: Bois de Vincennes
sites.description: The largest green space in Paris, on the eastern edge, featuring lakes, trails, a zoo, floral gardens, and the medieval Château de Vincennes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Popular for boating in summer; less crowded in winter.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket for park entry; book castle and zoo separately.

opening_hours.notes: Zoo and Château follow separate schedules.

closures.reason: Annual zoo maintenance (zoological park closed for 3 days)

transit.last_train_consideration: Easily accessible until ~00:45; park lit only along main paths.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Château de Vincennes interior visit.

sites.name: Saint-Germain-des-Prés Church
sites.description: One of the oldest churches in Paris, a serene pause between gallery hopping and café stops in Saint-Germain-des-Prés.
sites.seasonal_notes: Cool interior on hot days; occasional concerts in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No ticket needed; check parish schedule for special events.

visit_profile.weather_fallback: Musée d'Orsay

notable_events: The district's transformation in the 19th century

practical_info.walkability: Very walkable with hilly terrain offering great views.

practical_info.walkability: Very walkable with charming bridges and pathways.

activities.name: Cherry Blossom Viewing at Parc de Sceaux
activities.description: Experience the stunning cherry blossoms in full bloom at Parc de Sceaux, a short train ride from central Paris. The park is known for its expansive gardens and beautiful springtime displays.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring is the perfect time to enjoy the cherry blossoms, which typically bloom from late March to mid-April.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early to avoid crowds and bring a picnic blanket to enjoy a relaxing morning under the blossoms.

activities.name: Visit to the Orangerie Museum
activities.description: Discover Monet's famous Water Lilies and other remarkable Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works at the Orangerie Museum, located in the heart of the Tuileries Gardens.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring rains can be unpredictable, making an indoor museum visit an ideal activity.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online in advance to skip the lines and consider visiting on a weekday for a quieter experience.

activities.name: Nuit des Musées
activities.description: Participate in the Nuit des Musées, where many Parisian museums open their doors for free one night in May, offering special activities and exhibitions.
activities.seasonal_notes: This annual event celebrates culture and art, making it a must-do spring activity.
activities.booking_tips: Check the participating museums and plan your route in advance, as it can get busy.

activities.name: Picnic at Jardin des Tuileries
activities.description: Enjoy a leisurely picnic in the historic Jardin des Tuileries, surrounded by beautifully manicured gardens and sculptures.
activities.seasonal_notes: The gardens come alive in spring with blooming flowers and pleasant weather.
activities.booking_tips: Pick up fresh baguettes and cheese from a local boulangerie to enhance your picnic experience.

activities.name: Rooftop Bar at Le Perchoir
activities.description: Sip cocktails while enjoying panoramic views of Paris at Le Perchoir, a popular rooftop bar that offers a chic atmosphere.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring evenings are mild and perfect for enjoying outdoor terraces.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early to secure a good spot, especially on weekends.

activities.name: Foire du Trône
activities.description: Visit the Foire du Trône, the largest funfair in Paris, featuring rides, games, and food stalls. It runs from late March to late May.
activities.seasonal_notes: This spring festival is a traditional favorite for families and thrill-seekers.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase ride tickets in advance to avoid queues at the venue.

activities.name: Explore Montmartre
activities.description: Stroll through the charming streets of Montmartre, visiting iconic sites like the Sacré-Cœur Basilica and Place du Tertre.
activities.seasonal_notes: The spring weather is ideal for walking tours, with comfortable temperatures and blooming street gardens.
activities.booking_tips: Wear comfortable shoes and bring a camera to capture the picturesque streets.

activities.name: Canal Saint-Martin Cruise
activities.description: Enjoy a leisurely cruise along the Canal Saint-Martin, passing through charming locks and under romantic bridges.
activities.seasonal_notes: Springtime offers pleasant weather for outdoor cruises, with lush greenery along the canal.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets in advance, especially on weekends, to ensure availability.

activities.name: Springtime Markets
activities.description: Explore local spring markets, offering fresh produce, artisanal goods, and seasonal specialties, such as the Marché Bastille.
activities.seasonal_notes: Spring markets are bustling with seasonal produce and vibrant flowers.
activities.booking_tips: Visit early for the best selection and fewer crowds.

activities.name: Paris Plages
activities.description: The Seine riverbanks are transformed into temporary beaches with sand, deckchairs, and activities for all ages from mid-July to mid-August.
activities.seasonal_notes: This unique summer event brings the beach to the city, perfect for sunny days.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early to secure a spot, especially on weekends.

activities.name: Fireworks at Bastille Day
activities.description: Celebrate France's National Day on July 14th with spectacular fireworks at the Eiffel Tower and various festivities throughout the city.
activities.seasonal_notes: Bastille Day is a highlight of the summer, with patriotic celebrations and breathtaking fireworks.
activities.booking_tips: Find a good vantage point early in the evening to avoid the crowds and bring a picnic.

activities.name: Open-Air Cinema at Parc de la Villette
activities.description: Enjoy classic and contemporary films under the stars in Parc de la Villette's open-air cinema during July and August.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer evenings are perfect for outdoor cinema, with warm temperatures and late sunsets.
activities.booking_tips: Bring a blanket or a portable chair and arrive early to secure a good spot.

activities.name: Visit to the Palace of Versailles Gardens
activities.description: Explore the magnificent gardens of the Palace of Versailles, with fountains, groves, and the musical fountain shows.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer is the best time to see the gardens in full bloom, enhanced by musical fountain shows.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online and consider a weekday visit to avoid larger crowds.

activities.name: Jazz Festival at Parc Floral
activities.description: Attend the Paris Jazz Festival held at Parc Floral, featuring renowned jazz musicians and a beautiful botanical garden setting.
activities.seasonal_notes: The festival takes advantage of summer weather for outdoor performances amid lush gardens.
activities.booking_tips: Buy tickets in advance and bring a blanket for lounging on the grass.

activities.name: Cycling Along the Seine
activities.description: Rent a bike and cycle along the banks of the Seine, enjoying iconic views and pleasant summer breezes.
activities.seasonal_notes: The summer climate is ideal for outdoor cycling, with long daylight hours and scenic routes.
activities.booking_tips: Use a public bike-sharing service like Vélib' for convenience and accessibility.

activities.name: Rooftop Dining at Les Ombres
activities.description: Dine at Les Ombres, offering exquisite French cuisine with stunning views of the Eiffel Tower from its rooftop terrace.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer evenings are perfect for rooftop dining, with comfortable temperatures and spectacular sunsets.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve a table in advance, especially for sunset dining.

activities.name: Explore the Catacombs
activities.description: Venture into the Paris Catacombs, an underground network of tunnels and ossuaries containing the remains of over six million people.
activities.seasonal_notes: The catacombs offer a cool retreat from the summer heat and a unique historical experience.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets online to skip the queue, and wear comfortable shoes for walking.

activities.name: Seine River Dinner Cruise
activities.description: Enjoy a gourmet dinner aboard a Seine River cruise, with panoramic views of Paris's illuminated landmarks.
activities.seasonal_notes: Summer nights are ideal for river cruises, with balmy weather and stunning city lights.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve in advance and choose a window seat for the best views.

activities.name: Explore the Louvre Museum
activities.description: Visit the Louvre, the world's largest art museum, known for masterpieces like the Mona Lisa and the Venus de Milo.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn is a great time to explore indoor attractions as the weather cools down.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid long lines and consider a guided tour for deeper insights.

activities.name: Attend the Nuit Blanche
activities.description: Experience the Nuit Blanche, an all-night arts festival in October featuring contemporary art installations and performances throughout Paris.
activities.seasonal_notes: This annual event celebrates creativity and art, perfect for crisp autumn evenings.
activities.booking_tips: Check the program in advance and plan your route to catch your preferred exhibits.

activities.name: Wine Tasting in Montmartre
activities.description: Discover local wines with tastings at small wine bars in Montmartre, a historic wine-producing area of Paris.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn is harvest season in France, making it an ideal time for wine tasting.
activities.booking_tips: Reserve a spot at popular wine bars like Le Clos Montmartre for an intimate experience.

activities.name: Visit the Palais Garnier
activities.description: Tour the opulent Palais Garnier, home of the Paris Opera, and explore its stunning architecture and history.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn's cooler days are perfect for indoor activities like theater visits.
activities.booking_tips: Book a guided tour for exclusive access to behind-the-scenes areas.

activities.name: Autumn Walk in the Luxembourg Gardens
activities.description: Take a leisurely stroll through the Luxembourg Gardens, enjoying the fall foliage and serene atmosphere.
activities.seasonal_notes: The gardens are particularly beautiful in autumn with vibrant fall colors.
activities.booking_tips: Visit in the afternoon for the best lighting for photography.

activities.name: Visit to the Musée d'Orsay
activities.description: Explore the Musée d'Orsay, home to an extensive collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist masterpieces.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn's shorter days make museums an ideal choice for cultural enrichment.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues and consider a weekday visit for a quieter experience.

activities.name: Attend the Montmartre Grape Harvest Festival
activities.description: Join the festivities of the Montmartre Grape Harvest Festival in October, featuring parades, music, and local wine tastings.
activities.seasonal_notes: This local festival celebrates the autumn harvest, offering a unique cultural experience.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive early to enjoy the parade and secure a good spot for wine tastings.

activities.name: Explore the Covered Passages
activities.description: Wander through Paris's historic covered passages, featuring unique shops, cafes, and beautiful architecture.
activities.seasonal_notes: The covered passages provide a cozy retreat from the autumn chill.
activities.booking_tips: Take your time to explore passages like Galerie Vivienne and Passage des Panoramas.

activities.name: Attend a Cooking Class
activities.description: Learn to cook traditional French dishes with a hands-on cooking class, focusing on seasonal ingredients.
activities.seasonal_notes: Autumn's harvest provides a bounty of ingredients for culinary exploration.
activities.booking_tips: Book early, especially for popular classes, and check if the class includes a market visit.

activities.name: Ice Skating at Hôtel de Ville
activities.description: Enjoy ice skating on the outdoor rink set up in front of the Hôtel de Ville, a festive winter tradition in Paris.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is the perfect time for ice skating, with rinks set up around the city.
activities.booking_tips: Skate rentals are available on-site, but lines can be long, so arrive early.

activities.name: Visit to the Christmas Markets
activities.description: Explore Paris's charming Christmas markets, such as those at Champs-Élysées and La Défense, offering festive decorations, gifts, and seasonal treats.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter markets are a quintessential part of the holiday season, offering a warm, festive atmosphere.
activities.booking_tips: Visit in the evening for the best atmosphere and to see the festive lights.

activities.name: Attend a Concert at Sainte-Chapelle
activities.description: Experience a classical music concert in the stunning setting of Sainte-Chapelle, known for its breathtaking stained glass windows.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter evenings are perfect for indoor concerts, providing warmth and cultural enrichment.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets in advance, as concerts often sell out quickly.

activities.name: Explore the Musée de l'Orangerie
activities.description: Visit the Musée de l'Orangerie to see Monet's Water Lilies and other Impressionist masterpieces, offering a warm retreat from the winter cold.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter's cold makes it an ideal time for indoor art appreciation.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to skip the queues and consider a guided tour for deeper insights.

activities.name: Hot Chocolate at Angelina
activities.description: Warm up with a famous hot chocolate at Angelina, a historic Parisian café known for its rich and creamy chocolat chaud.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is the perfect season for enjoying indulgent hot beverages.
activities.booking_tips: Arrive during off-peak times to avoid long wait times, especially on weekends.

activities.name: Visit to the Palace of Versailles
activities.description: Tour the opulent Palace of Versailles and its expansive gardens, less crowded during the winter months.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter offers fewer crowds, allowing a more leisurely exploration of the palace.
activities.booking_tips: Purchase tickets online to avoid queues and consider an audio guide for a self-paced tour.

activities.name: Attend Opera at Palais Garnier
activities.description: Enjoy a performance at the Palais Garnier, one of the most beautiful opera houses in the world, offering a mix of opera and ballet.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter is an ideal season for indoor performances, combining culture with warmth and elegance.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets well in advance, as popular performances sell out quickly.

activities.name: Visit the Notre-Dame Cathedral
activities.description: Explore the historic Notre-Dame Cathedral, a masterpiece of French Gothic architecture, and admire its stunning interior.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter offers a serene atmosphere for visiting iconic landmarks with fewer tourists.
activities.booking_tips: Check restoration updates and consider attending a service for a unique experience.

activities.name: Seine River Cruise
activities.description: Experience a Seine River cruise, offering heated indoor seating and panoramic views of Paris's illuminated winter skyline.
activities.seasonal_notes: Winter cruises provide a cozy vantage point to appreciate the city's winter beauty.
activities.booking_tips: Book tickets online and choose a cruise with indoor seating for warmth.

scoreDescription.1: Poor: Unfavorable conditions, extreme weather, overcrowded or limited activities, poor value
scoreDescription.2: Below Average: Less ideal conditions, possibly unpleasant weather or very high crowds, limited value

scoreDescription.4: Good: Very favorable conditions, pleasant weather, manageable crowds, good value
